The April 8 Chess column discusses the new blight of cheating in chess tournaments (''As Technology Leaps Ahead, Concerns About Cheating Grow''). I am reminded of a story told to me by Olga Capablanca, the widow of the world chess champion José Raúl Capablanca.

Capa was playing in a tournament in Russia in the 1930s. Some of the best in the world's best were competing, including Soviets and foreigners. A famous personality arrived to watch the event: Stalin.
The dictator approached Capablanca and asked, ''How do you like my tournament?''
Capa replied, ''It's terrible; your players are cheating.''
Capa: ''When they play against each other, the Soviets make quick draws and they get to rest. When they play against me, they fight on and on just to make me tired.''
Allen Kaufman Forest Hills, Queens April 11, 2007
The writer was executive director of the American Chess Foundation, 1978-99.
